subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Characters #28 & #30 Changes?
msgSnippet: If I may chime in on this point, the proposed solutions just seem very tortured from a penmanship point of view.  Just try them in the air, with big sweeps
messageBody:
Re: [Read_Alphabet] Characters #28 & #30 Changes?
If I may chime in on this point, the proposed solutions just seem very tortured from a "penmanship" point of view.  Just try them in the air, with big sweeps like you were conducting an orchestra, and you will see what I mean.  It's like tracing the flight of a drunken moth.

I agree that, for me too, QS has proven a write-only language.  I have developed speed in writing, but reading speed seems not to have improved in a year's work.  I'm glad to see that I'm not alone in this phenomenon.  There must be two different parts of the brain at work for coding, and uncoding the information.





On Tue, 2003-05-27 at 13:34, Chuck Peck wrote:
> A possible solution for this would be to modify the
> #28 & #30 characters to make them distinct from a
> connecting stroke. The attached pictures are examples
> of a possible modification to them that might help.

As an on-the side, devil's advocate, discussion point only, NOT as a
serious proposal, how about leaving the letters alone, for backward
compatibility, but make two new connecting strokes?

For example, there are no diagonal strokes that go between the base line
and middle line. 'W' and 'WH' will not be confused because they start
deep, however the various curvey letters (like AH, AW, OH, EH) might if
poorly formed.  [Example enclosed]

HOWEVER, after seeing both Chuck's modified letters and the diagonal
connectors proposed here, my personal preference would be to leave
things alone on on this issue.  They both add some visual confusion and
clutter in exchange for avoiding one pen lift.   In both cases, the
actual amount of written material is more.

I think most people would agree that unless you have many years of QS,
it's a write-only language.  It's much easier to write quickly than
read, because of how our minds have been trained.  My point here is that
we don't want to make it even harder to decipher by adding more lines
that will be mistaken as text.

So I would urge a no vote here...

Regards,
--
Mitchell Perilstein
